caption.p:
Antarctic climate record exhibiting warming trend at ~12,800 cal BP. Changes in methane (CH 4) concentrations are used to identify and correlate climate change boundaries representing the Antarctic Cold Reversal and the Younger Dryas. Climatic history is reflected by changes in δ 18O and δD values, which are proxies for temperature, with lower values indicating cooler climate. ( a) Byrd core in West Antarctica; ( b) EPICA Dome C near the center of East Antarctica; ( c) TALDICE core from Talos Dome in southern East Antarctica; ( d) green upper curve represents global mean ocean temperature from WAIS divide near Byrd in West Antarctica. Purple lower curve represents atmospheric temperatures reconstructed from CO 2 record at EPICA Dome C
140 . Blue vertical bar represents cooler climate during the Antarctic Cold Reversal, anti-phased with the warm Bølling-Allerød episode in the Northern Hemisphere. Orange vertical bar represents warmer climate in Antarctic coeval with Younger Dryas cooling in the Northern Hemisphere. Blue and red arrows indicate colder or warmer temperature changes, respectively, across the Antarctic Cold Reversal and the Younger Dryas.
